<div class="bio">
Ph.D. candidate in Agricultural & Applied Economics specializing in quantitative, data-intensive farm management. I work at the intersection of applied econometrics, statistical learning, and agronomic modeling, building production-theory-guided models in R and Python for geospatial and field-scale data. My research blends causal inference, Bayesian modeling, and machine-learning pipelines to understand input responses, environmental risk, and decision-making under uncertainty—interests I aim to bring into data science economist roles.
</div>
